message: Hello, Facebook! Like my page for updates!
I'm excited to be sworn in as Congressman and get to work for the 4th District of Kansas. Watch the swearing in ceremony live on CSPAN at 5:40pm Central.   https://www.c-span.org/networks/

ICYMI: Here is video of my swearing-in on the House floor yesterday evening. I'm grateful to have had my family with me and to my good friend Rep. Lynn Jenkins for her very kind words. Looking forward to working for Kansas in Congress!

Our thoughts and prayers go with the soldiers of the 35th Infantry Division as they deploy to the Middle East to support Operation Spartan Shield. I'm very grateful to them and their families for their service and sacrifice.
It was a pleasure meeting with members of the Community Bankers Association of Kansas today. Thanks for all the excellent work you do for our local communities and businesses!
NA
The message from Kansas voters during last month‚Äôs special election was crystal clear: Produce results or go home.  Check out my full op-ed in The Wall Street Journal here:

The AHCA is a historic first step toward putting people ‚Äì not politics ‚Äì back at the center of our health care system.  The voters of the 4th District sent me to Congress to find solutions to complex issues facing our country.  Obamacare has unquestionably hurt more people than it has helped, and it has forced Americans to buy insurance they don‚Äôt like, don‚Äôt need, and can‚Äôt afford.  I‚Äôm very pleased that we were able to pass the first step in a multi-step process to repeal and replace Obamacare.

It was an incredible week. Many Kansans visiting our offices, several great meetings, staff getting up and running to serve constituents, we voted to repeal and replace Obamacare, and I was even able to chair a joint subcommittee meeting. Now looking forward to a productive week back in the 4th District!

There has been quite a bit of misinformation regarding the first step in a multi-step process to repeal and replace Obamacare.  Here are the facts about the American Health Care Act (AHCA):  Dismantles the Obamacare taxes that have hurt job creators, increased premium costs, and limited options for patients and health care providers‚Äîincluding taxes on prescription drugs, over-the-counter medications, health-insurance premiums, and medical devices.    Eliminates the individual and employer mandate penalties, which forced millions of workers, families, and job creators into expensive, Obamacare plans that they don‚Äôt want and cannot afford.   Helps young adults access health insurance and stabilize the marketplace by allowing dependents to continue staying on their parents‚Äô plan until they are 26.   Guarantees coverage to Americans with pre-existing conditions and bans health insurers from charging a patient with pre-existing conditions higher premiums as long as they maintain continuous coverage, or sign up for new coverage within 63 days of exiting a previous insurance plan.   Establishes a Patient and State Stability Fund and Federal Invisible Risk Sharing Program, which provides states with $130 billion to design programs that meet the unique needs of their patient populations, help low-income Americans afford health care, and provide a backstop safety net for Americans with pre-existing conditions. This includes $15 billion specifically toward mental health and substance abuse and newborn care.   Modernizes and strengthens Medicaid by transitioning to a ‚Äúper capita allotment‚Äù so states can better serve the patients most in need. The Medicaid reform represents the biggest entitlement reform in a generation and puts the program on a sustainable fiscal path.    Protects current Medicaid beneficiaries receiving health care under the expansion by honoring the enhanced state match they have been receiving, while working to redirect able-bodied adults to private health care so Medicaid can be refocused on helping the most vulnerable.    Empowers individuals and families to spend their health care dollars the way they want and need by enhancing and expanding Health Savings Accounts (HSAs)‚Äînearly doubling the amount of money people can contribute and broadening how people can use it.    Helps Americans access affordable, quality health care by providing a monthly tax credit‚Äî between $2,000 and $14,000 a year‚Äîfor low- and middle-income individuals and families who don‚Äôt receive insurance through work or a government program. Americans can use this tax credit to purchase private, quality coverage of their choice.
This is an excellent piece by Congresswoman Cathy McMorris Rodgers explaining the protections for people with pre-existing conditions in the American Health Care Act.

Great things are happening with NexStep Alliance, a partnership of Goodwill Industries of Kansas and Wichita Area Technical College. Thank you for the tour and the educational opportunities you offer to our community.
The honor was mine. Envision is doing amazing things to empower people and integrate resources that help those with visual impairment. Thank you for the great meeting and tour!

Earlier this week I was fortunate to meet many students and faculty at L'Ouverture Elementary, West High and Levy Special Education Center in Wichita. Wichita Public Schools have some fantastic hands-on learning tools being used to educate our next generation. My sincere appreciation to the teachers and staff for their dedication to these kids.

GraceMed Health Clinic CEO Dave Sanford was kind enough to give me a tour of the recently opened Virginia & George Ablah Family Clinic in south Wichita. GraceMed is doing incredible work to advance their mission of delivering quality health care and compassion to our community.
Enjoyed a great conversation with Kyle Bauer at KFRM 550 AM Farm Radio. Tune in TODAY at 2:30pm CT to hear it, or stream it online.

On this day, National Peace Officers Memorial Day, I am profoundly grateful to our law enforcement community for all they do to keep us safe. This week, please join me in thanking our fellow Kansans who work so diligently to protect and serve.
Looking forward to joining Lou Dobbs tonight at 6:40 PM Central / 7:40 PM Eastern on the FOX Business Network. Hope you'll tune in!

I enjoyed a productive week reporting back to my fellow Kansans and engaging with constituents across the district. Read my full letter to the editor here. And thank you, Deb Lucia, for your very kind letter as well!
Wonderful to visit with friends and business leaders from the Wichita Regional Chamber of Commerce today. Glad to see so many Kansans in DC!
ICYMI: Here are my comments with Lou Dobbs last night. Ultimately, we all should want America to be successful.

My statement on the appointment of former FBI Director Robert Mueller as Special Counsel to the investigation of alleged Russian efforts to influence the 2016 presidential election and related matters:  In a case of such public interest, it is imperative to foster confidence and independence to assure the American people that we are still a nation grounded in the rule of law.  I have confidence in former Director Mueller and the professionals at the U.S. Department of Justice to give us a full and fact-based account of any possible efforts to undermine our election process.  As this investigation progresses ‚Äì as well as those of the House and Senate Committees ‚Äì it is important to give the process and people involved our support and patience.  I support the appointment of former Director Mueller as Special Counsel.
Wonderful seeing Dr. Mildred Edwards and Kenya Cox during their visit to Washington with The Links, Incorporated. Thank you for stopping by my office!

Congressman Ron Estes (KS-4) released the following statement today on the decision by Blue Cross Blue Shield of Kansas City to pull out of Obamacare.  ‚ÄúObamacare is clearly broken and Congress must fix it. The law is collapsing before our eyes. In Kansas and across the country, millions of Americans are hurting and rightfully concerned about what will happen next.‚Äù    ‚ÄúThis decision highlights the urgent need to replace Obamacare.  I was proud to support the American Health Care Act which passed the House earlier this month.  The law will help the very people affected by this decision by making care more affordable and accessible. The best way to provide great care to all Americans is to build a patient-centered system focused on the individual. As today‚Äôs news show, putting government at the center of healthcare just doesn‚Äôt work.‚Äù
Hot off the press! My official e-newsletter is up and running. Read the first one here, where you can also sign up to receive future updates.
So glad we were able to help. I hope everyone enjoys a safe Memorial Day weekend.

Established to honor those who have died serving our nation in the Armed Forces, Memorial Day is a time of solemn remembrance. Originally known as Decoration Day after the Civil War, the observance of Memorial Day evolved alongside America‚Äôs continued fight for freedom and liberty, until finally becoming a federal holiday in 1971.  Today is a day to remember our fallen heroes who made the ultimate sacrifice in service to the United States of America. Many of them perhaps were our Kansas neighbors, friends, or even family members. They laid down their lives so that we may live free in the greatest nation on Earth.  As we enjoy our freedom with family and friends, let it be in a spirit of deep gratitude for the warriors who purchased it with their lives. Moreover, please take the opportunity to thank our soldiers, sailors, airmen, and Marines, who bravely stand ready to fight for America and preserve freedom, no matter the cost.

It was a tremendous honor to spend Memorial Day weekend with our troops at the National Training Center/Fort Irwin. Soldiers from several states, including Kansas, demonstrated again why our forces truly are second-to-none. I am very grateful for their service.

I share President Trump‚Äôs desire to make travel in America‚Äôs airspace safer, more efficient and technologically advanced.  However, any plans for privatization of our air traffic control system must also take into consideration the impact on general aviation.  Wichita is the Air Capital of the World and we have pioneered general aviation for decades.  Any updates to America's air traffic control system must ensure the safety of American air passengers and protect the needs of general aviation.  I look forward to reviewing the proposal laid out by the President today.
73 years ago today, thousands of Americans marched onto the shores of Europe to face tremendous evil. We should never forget the sacrifice given by these patriots. Please share if you agree.
My latest e-newsletter went out yesterday. Did you receive your copy? Click here to read past editions and sign up!
Proud to be voting for the Financial CHOICE Act today! Here are 10 ways this piece of legislation will help Americans.

Glad to meet with some of my former State Treasurer colleagues to discuss financial issues today. It was wonderful to see Idaho State Treasurer Ron Crane, Kentucky State Treasurer Allison Ball, and State Financial Officers Foundation President Derek Kreifels.

I was proud to vote for and cosponsor the Financial CHOICE Act.  Repealing the burdensome regulations in the Dodd-Frank Act is a solution to repair one of President Obama's most disastrous policies.  This CHOICE Act will accomplish what Dodd-Frank was designed to do‚Äîholding large banks accountable for their actions while also allowing economic growth.  The Financial CHOICE Act will allow our local banks to once again be able to provide Kansans with the financing they need to buy homes and create small businesses.
My op-ed on repealing Obama‚Äôs regulatory nightmare. www.kansas.com/opinion/opn-columns-blogs/article155445894.html

I‚Äôd like to highlight the tremendous work of the AbilityOne program. I enjoyed learning about it with the folks at Envision back in May.   AbilityOne is a federal program that helps Americans who have significant disabilities obtain employment. Through it, many individuals who are blind, or are wounded warriors, have been able to obtain employment. In fact, more than 45,000 have found jobs through this program. Like my page to learn more.

America's veterans should not be forced to fight through a bureaucratic labyrinth in order to receive the care they deserve.  Often times, when abuses have come to light at the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department has been unable to hold its employees accountable due to excessive bureaucratic red tape.    This is now going to change.  The Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act of 2017 will guarantee that bad actors are punished, as well as provide whistleblowers with important safeguards so that abuses can come to light sooner.  Our veterans deserve to receive the highest quality of care.
‚Ä™Please keep Congressman Steve Scalise, his staff, and law enforcement officers who were involved in your thoughts and prayers.‚Ä¨

Tonight‚Äôs Congressional ballgame is about more than baseball. It‚Äôs about Americans standing united against those who would seek to use violence to divide us.   In America, we have always faced tough political debates ‚Äî what makes us exceptional is that when we disagree, we don‚Äôt become disagreeable. This is why I am proud to be a part of this bipartisan event that celebrates America.  The game is at 6 PM CT: https://www.c-span.org/video/?429988-1/2017-congressional-baseball-game

The Congressional baseball game is a great bipartisan event. I would like to thank the Capitol Police for protecting us everyday. Our prayers go out for Rep. Steve Scalise and we wish him a speedy recovery.

I introduced HR 3383 today, which will rename the Wichita-Valley Center Flood Control Project the M.S Mitchell Floodway. Mr. Mitchell was a visionary, whose long service to Wichita in public works and flood control led to the project‚Äôs completion. The Big Ditch has saved lives, prevented millions of dollars in property damage, and allowed for expanded growth and opportunity within our region. It is appropriate that it be named after its chief architect and a true Wichita hero

I support President Trump‚Äôs reversal of this unconstitutional Obama-era executive order.  This decision gives Congress time to fix our broken immigration system.  Congress can do this by securing our borders, reviewing our immigration process, and not providing amnesty to those who disregard our nation‚Äôs laws.

I was pleased to address the Homeland Security and Defense Business Council with Oversight and Management Efficiency Subcommittee Chairman Scott Perry this morning. As a member of the Homeland Security Committee, I take very seriously the responsibility to keep America safe.

My heart goes out to all of those in Houston and the Gulf region who have had their lives turned upside down by Hurricane Harvey. Americans and private organizations who came to their aid without preconditions or expecting anything in return represent the best of the American spirit. While I was proud to support a relief bill without preconditions in the House, I could not support the Senate version that essentially used the relief bill to bailout Washington politicians who don't want to do the hard work of setting priorities and living within our means. Congress should respond to this terrible storm, but we can't ignore the approaching fiscal storm. We need to prepare for that storm today and bring down our debt, not put it off until tomorrow.

We must never forget the 2,977 lives lost on Sept. 11, 2001. My thoughts and prayers go out to all those who lost loved ones on that horrible day. On this anniversary of 9/11, America remains committed to combating Islamist terrorism around the globe.

It was great to meet with Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai today at the Sedgwick County Emergency Communications Center. He's been instrumental in helping to roll back burdensome government regulations on the Internet. We don't need government bureaucrats and lawyers running the Internet. A free market system is key to ensuring that the Internet remains a hub of innovation. In the Chairman's words, "If it ain't broke, then we don't need to government to fix it." Mr. Pai, who grew up in Parsons, KS Ì†ºÌºª, is an advocate for expanding Internet access to rural areas.

I am very proud to be a cosponsor of "Micah's Bill" (H.R.36 - Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act) which is being brought to the House floor for a vote today. I had the pleasure of meeting Micah last week. He was born just past 22 weeks, and was the size of an M&M packet at birth (Look close to see the photo of him at birth that I'm holding). Micah's a fun-loving, energetic, normal kid. He's proof that all life is sacred. It's time to stop late term abortions in America.

The Border Security for America Act authorizes a border wall, secures ports of entry, and adds 5,000 border agents. It also will target those who overstay their visas through full use of the Biometric Entry-Exit System at all ports of entry ~ Homeland Security Committee #BorderSecurityforAmerica   Visit here to learn more: https://homeland.house.gov/border-security-for-america-act/

Last night 3 American soldiers were killed and 2 were wounded while helping local forces in the Northwestern African nation of Niger fight an Al-Qaeda insurgency. Please take time today to say a prayer or to hold a moment of silence for these brave soldiers who were injured, or who gave the ultimate sacrifice. They fought for justice and for civilization on behalf of our great nation. May God bless all our servicemembers who put their lives at risk each and every day to defend our liberty and freedoms.   https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/04/world/africa/special-forces-killed-niger.html

Americans shouldn't be forced to violate their faith. Glad to see the Trump Administration change this controversial Obama-era HHS rule, which forced many Americans to violate their faith without regard to the First Amendment.   http://dailysignal.com/2017/10/06/trump-administration-undoes-obamacares-egregious-assault-on-religious-freedom-conscience-rights/

I applaud the Trump administration's dedication to ending the Obama administration's war on affordable energy. This regulation would have raised the cost-of-living for hardworking families in Kansas without actually improving the environment. The Clean Power Plan, and many other regulations put in place under the previous administration, were enacted without regard to the cost that would have to be paid by the American public. Don't let the title fool you, the Clean Power Plan didn't even regulate pollutants generated from power plants.

I spoke on the House floor today about the need for real tax reform:  "Our outdated and overly complex tax code has held our economy down for the past decade --- It‚Äôs time we fix this and empower working families in America."   "Real tax reform will be the best way to help Americans climb up the economic ladder. A stronger economy will bring higher wages, and better jobs. The goal is to make our federal code simple and to make it fair. The tax code as it is, only benefits the rich and well-connected who can hire an army of lawyers to protect their interests. This is why Republicans are looking to enact real reform for all Americans."
Own a business? We want to hear your story. Please follow the link to fill out the short survey: https://estes.house.gov/forms/form/?ID=6  Thank you!

The tax reform framework will completely update America's tax system. Read the 8 page tax reform framework here: https://fairandsimple.gop/?utm_source=RepRonEstes  The tax reform framework will simplify our tax code and make it fairer by allowing  low-and middle-income workers to keep more of their hard-earned paychecks in order to save for their children‚Äôs college, or for their retirement.

Yesterday, I spoke on the House floor in support of the Save Local Business Act ‚Äì legislation that will restore a commonsense definition of employer to provide certainty and stability for workers and employers. Today, on #VeteransDay, we honor all those who have donned the uniform and served our great nation. We thank you from the bottom of our heart for sacrificing much in order to protect our freedoms and our liberty.

I enjoyed visiting with many veterans today around our community. Susan and I attended the Veterans Day parade as well as the celebration of a true Kansas hero, the late Sgt. Sus Gonzales. Sgt. Gonzales died of battle wounds in 1945 a day after being recognized by the Bristish government for bravery because of his assistance of a British unit during the war. His family didn't know of the recognition until it was recently discovered and reissued. Today, his sister, 93-year-old Esther, accepted the Distinguished Conduct Medal on his behalf. There‚Äôs no doubt that Sgt. Gonzales‚Äô selfless actions saved countless others.   Thank you to all our incredible veterans across Kansas. May God bless them and the United States of America.

We're one step closer to tax relief for millions of Americans. For more than three decades, families have paid a growing cost for our country‚Äôs increasingly complex and burdensome tax code that's loaded with special interest loopholes. This isn‚Äôt fair to hardworking Kansans. That's why today I voted for the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.

The Department of Homeland Security has proposed to conduct a chemical test at the Chilocco Indian School campus in Oklahoma, not far from Ark City. While it's important for our federal agencies to test their abilities in response to threats, we need to be one hundred percent certain this test is safe. Kansans have a right to know what is happening near their homes and I will do whatever it takes to keep our community safe.   I am working to make sure all questions are answered before any more action is taken. The process the Department used to inform residents was inadequate and I encourage Kansans to utilize the DHS comment period to voice their opinions on the proposed test.   To do so, you can email comments along with your name and address to biotest@hq.dhs.gov, or you can mail your comments to:   S&T CBD Mail Stop 0201 245 Murray Ln SW Washington, DC 20528-0201  For more information: https://www.dhs.gov/publication/st-draft-environmental-assessment-proposed-outdoor-testing-chilocco

Family farms and businesses are the backbone of the Kansas economy. Last week I had the privilege of touring one of those Kansas success stories, Budde Enterprises. In the past 50 years, Budde Enterprises has grown from a small family farm in Harvey County to a custom fabrication and repair shop that serves the transportation and agriculture industries. Budde Enterprises is one of many thriving small businesses that strengthen the local economy and enhances the community. Read more about my visit in the Newton Kansan at www.thekansan.com/news/20171120/estes-tours-budde.

It was moving to watch as Brian Arterburn, a Wichita hero and a true servant of the people, returned home after months of recovery in Colorado and Texas. Brian was severely injured while protecting and serving his fellow citizens. The Wichita community and beyond has rallied around and prayed for Brian and his family during this difficult time. He certainly deserves our gratitude and respect. Welcome home, Brian!

There is no place for sexual harassment in our society and there is no excuse for such offenses. As the father of two daughters, it makes me sick to hear the stories which have recently come to light from within Hollywood, the media, Capitol Hill and statehouses around the country including Kansas. We must hold abusers accountable for their transgressions, and do everything we can to prevent future abuse.  It's clear that this isn't just a problem within any one industry but a widespread cultural problem across our country that must be addressed. I support policies that will strengthen reporting protocols and believe we must increase prevention training.   Today the House passed H.Res 630, which mandates yearly sexual harassment training for members and staff, which my entire staff has already completed. No one should have to deal with sexual harassment at work.
